title: This video about Tencent needs more visibility
body:
EDIT: Just so everyone knows, it's come to the attention of quite a few people that there is no discernible link between Tencent and Sesame Credit, despite what the video says. Everything else in the video may or may not hold up to scrutiny but until concrete evidence links those two things, it's not Riot's problem and this thread is simply a discussion of the situation in China with Sesame Credit. That said, I think we'd all appreciate a knowledgeable Rioter (perhaps they know as little as we do and therefore refrain from commenting) telling us more. Information is key here.

Especially Riot employees should see this and reconsider their affiliation with one of the most sinister and oppressive companies in the world, Tencent.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lHcTKWiZ8sI

It's Orwellian, it's malicious, and it's despicable. Riot ought to address the horrors going on in their parent company somehow.

I thought China was already really fucked up? This seems like one more fucked up thing about China added to the pile of shit we all already knew about

The real danger isn't what this does to china, though that already would be bad enough, but what this implies.

This system in china is a prototype of a new incredible potent form of mass manipulation. The big danger is that other systems, be it goverments, religiions or corporates, adapt that system and further develope it, getting a smarter and way more suptile aproach than china.

Edit:
After further research, it appears that Sesame Credit is not more than a chinse version of FICO-Rating or Shufa. So a raw credit-rating with no political intentions.
( a good article on this subject: http://qz.com/519737/all-chinese-citizens-now-have-a-score-based-on-how-well-we-live-and-mine-sucks/)

However, the chinise goverment is indeed planeing a social credit score for 2020, haveing a competion of serveral credit scores as pilot projects for the governmental credit score, with the most prominent one beeing sesame credit.
So while sesam credit atleast for now is a raw credit rateing system, it probably will serv as fundation for a govermental system.
There is actually not much known about that govermental system besides the directive.

The problem is that the directive is very vague, while it does not directly state that data is used as implyed by extracredits, it also does not say thatz it will not.

from the directive:

  
>   ....establishing the idea of an sincerity culture, and carrying forward sincerity and traditional virtues, it uses encouragement to keep trust and constraints against breaking trust as incentive mechanisms, and its objective is raising the honest mentality and credit levels of the entire society.
>     (....)
>     Government promotion, joint construction with society. Fully give rein to the organizational, guiding, promoting and demonstration roles of government. The government is responsible for formulating and implementing development plans, completing regulations and standards, fostering and supervising credit service markets
>     (....)
>     foster good habits of sincerity and trust-keeping,
>     (...)
>     ...and guide toe construction of professional ethics and behavioural norms.

I think the main problem is that in this context, the definition of terms like 'honest mentallity', 'professional ethics' and 'behavioural norms' is not given. Combined with the frequent mention of 'Government promotion', this certainly hints to the possibility that the definitions of 'good habits of sincerity and trust-keeping' and such will be up to the goverment, and while the directive does not push one to interpretations such as the one in extra credits, it certainly does allow for such interpretations, and the though of it isn't far fetched.

i'm still very skeptic towards what happens in china,as they are creating a social credit rateing(and actually serveral credit rateings for everything, includeing rateing systems) with reward/punishment systems, and they use lots of data for that, which gets suppostly provided by alibaba(though this isn't confimed by alibaba) weehboo and so on(though that doesn't really differ much from the western world, only that china is more open about data collection) but it's not as bad as extracredits makes it look like, especially in how far tencent is involved on it.

However, the idea of an establishment useing gameification in a similar way as presented by extracredits remains most unsettling.

_Disclaimer: I only did skim the directive and i am by far expert for such things, so take this with a grain of salt and look into the directive your self._

HOLY.  SHIT.  

This is literally the prototype to the Sybil System.

As much as I absolutely can't stand Extra Credits, they made a good point with propaganda games, and this shit is unbelievable.  This is really scary.  Like, really, REALLY scary.

Sybil system was designed to prevent crimes by finding people that would commit it. It worked decent for that perpose even thought it was far from perfect and stepping on moral boundaries.

On the other hand this highly immoral and is designed to manipulate people toward ~~patriotism~~ ethnicism in order to control them. Classical chinese goverment. It has taken a lot similar actions so stepping into social media does not surprise me. But gonna admit i would never expect that level.

The Sybil System was designed as a means of social order.  So is the Sesame Score.

The Sybil System is the extreme personification of the Sesame Score.  It models you around what society expects of you, and you get branded a "latent criminal" or in this case "unpatriotic".  You get your rights taken away from you, and if it's high enough, thrown in prison or executed on the spot.

The Sybil System was so unbelievably bad that a woman got beaten to death in the street by some dude wearing a helmet that mimicked the Psycho-Pass of the last person he saw, and people literally just stood around and watched.  They had no clue on how to respond to danger, because Sybil had ingrained in the minds of the public that the system was perfect at catching criminals and preserving order, even though a woman literally got beaten to death right in front of them.  To add insult to injury, just before she died, she got a warning from the government, because her Psycho-Pass got cloudy (you know, because I"m sure you wouldn't be completely stress free if you were being beaten to death).  I'm not even talking about the "criminally asymptomatic" assholes that literally could slit someone's throat out in public without registering a single point on their Psycho-Passes.

This kind of shit really isn't that far off.  Sesame Scores are going to be mandatory in 2020, and while a system that can adequately measure someone's mental health status from just scanning them is something not happening anytime soon, using China's version of Facebook to weed out potential political dissidents before they can spread their message is particularly powerful.  Not to mention, they don't even need to punish them and censor them, because using positive and negative reinforcement, they can use social ostracization to do all the work for you.  Like they said in the video; fear is negative and breeds resentment.  Assassinations and government purges and other means of suppressing the populace build resentment.  But social ostracization is extremely benign and most people would never see it as an attack on their freedoms, just keeping out the undesirables that would harm their perfect society.

So while it's good to raise public awareness, Riot is not only never going to respond, but they're not able to effect the change the op wants.

Basically, this video is about awareness. It may happen at some point that this kind of a system gets implemented in our countries and we should know what the problems are to ensure that doesn't happen. 

As an example, in India Facebook tied up with TRAI(Telecom Regulatory Authority of India) which is basically a government branch that deals with telecommunication and internet, to implement some kind of permit for private telephone companies to ensure some websites get high speeds while others don't, Facebook being one of them. So basically, these telephone companies would charge you additional money for services that allowed internet calling like Skype and Whatsapp or chatting like Hangouts or Telegram for normal or high speeds. If you didn't pay that money, the speeds of these services and websites would be so slow, that you won't be able to use them anyway. (.l.. you Mark Zuckerberg). In gaming terms, if my telephone company gets paid by Blizzard, then I would only have good ping playing WoW. If I decided to play league, I wont be able to, because my speed and ping would be off the charts. At the same time, my neighbor with a telecom company paid by Riot, would have perfect speed for league, but will have problems with WoW or other games.

So this buncha guys who had a youtube channel called [AIB](https://www.youtube.com/user/allindiabakchod) managed to catch it made a similar video to raise awareness for it and promote the people to take a stand against this stupid ruling called [Save the Internet](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mfY1NKrzqi0) which was viewed by a HUGE number of people. The people took a stand threatening the government and, being the largest democracy, the government bowed to the pressure and stopped it going any further. 

TL; DR: These guys are trying to make you aware how you can be controlled sneakily without having any idea till its too late. Making you aware right now ensure you are able to take a stand if something like this ever gets implemented in your country. :)

I don't really see this as an issue with the big companies in China, as much as an issue with China as a country. 

The government requested this system, and in an Authoritarian State, can those companies honestly deny the government? They have a huge amount of their power base in China. Tencent buys into all these foreign game companies ,because traditionally Chinese Business strategies fail outside of china due to how enclosed and specific the market there is.

Sure it sounds noble to say 'Well, they could just leave China and take a stand for liberty and freedom!' but that's not so easy. That would cost millions of people their jobs, and would ruin these companies (and I can't think of a single company that willingly and intentionally would destroy itself to make a political point).

So while you can certainly blame these companies for making an effective system, this video certainly doesn't provide anywhere near the evidence that would suggest that these companies are enthusiastic about the idea, or doing it with malicious intent.
They may in fact be being coerced and are unwilling participants in this scheme; that said, it does not mean that their actions are justifiable or that the company should continue to be supported.

Oh yeah, I wasn't trying to say they're innocent, since they did get involved with this operation. I was just pointing out it's not as black and white as 'Tencent are evil!' which is what it sort of feels this thread is suggesting, and something the video didn't really address either.

I do agree with your general sentiment that there is really nothing Riot can do about it; practically speaking they can't. They're owned by Tencent, and short of buying up all of their shares somehow they have no real recourse.

The article is written irresponsibly. Since the source it based on is a fabricated story. "open sesame" will open the door of hidden treasures for "Ali baba" (the company name behind it) based on Arabia fairy tales. Isn't it obvious this is at best a marketing stunt?
"Sesame Credit System" is a 3rd party online reputation (called Credit but not really) evaluation and tracking system run within the boundary of services provided by "Alibaba", the giant internet company in China equivalent of Amazon+Ebay+Facebook. While this system is based on big data, it takes in user's internet posts, the product you bought, etc into account, then produces a credit score, which is used if you want to apply loan from the same company, all this happens within the boundaries of services provided by one company, Alibaba. So it is not too different from Amazon reputation, or Reddit karma. The difference is the sesame score is cleverly named "Credit Score" and it has a range between 0 and 900, to confuse people, especially those who lives in the US
"Credit China" is a government run business complaint/case history tracking system, similar to BBB. It claims it also tracks 900k individuals, or 0.08% of the total population, however these individuals are most likely business representatives. This system does NOT generate a credit score as result. Unlike what the article claimed.
The two systems are not linked in any way. So, the foundation of the article is based on a frictional, "would-be" story. The article assumes Ali's credit system is the ultimate version of government credit system. It's easy to see that is unlikely and not feasible because government does not have access to the intimate details of buyer-seller relation, among other information. They may attempt to do it in a secret way, somehow. However, will they use secret info in a public credit score? My guess is unlikely.
You must realize no matter how big Alibaba is, they still have competitors (in fact, many huge companies as competitors), and China also have anti-monopoly laws. Alibaba's system is not implementable at the State level, because it requires a virtual monopoly of e-commerce, online communication, phone, etc by ONE company. Be it private or state-owned, that is the end of Chinese economy.
So even if the government will build a social credit system, it will be likely NOT based on online communications, your message on discussion forums, or buying/selling records. Those are still within each private company's database (like Alibaba). More likely, (and this is just my speculation) the government system is based on record of debt collection, loan, tax etc just like the US credit system today. The difference might be that it will be a government department, not three independent organizations, that keep credit scores. Then, there is the question of if your credit score needs to be accessible by other people. In most countries, you can pay a fee to get to know other people's credit score, for example, as part of background check. How easy/difficult Chinese government will make this process be, I can not predict.

Not much different from how the USA works to be fairly honest. At least China's rather open about it.

Actually, China isn't exactly a democratic nation. Even though you get to elect a President, you can't make a different party with different ideals to propose another candidate. For example the US has a two party system: Republican and Democrat. So unless the candidate is standing as an individual, the presidential candidates will belong to either of these two parties. India on the other hand, has a multiple party system. It means that citizens of India can make as many parties as they like and propose candidates from them for the elections. However China, has a single party system. So the candidates who will stand for presidential elections will be from one party only. If this were applied to the US system, you would only be able to elect a Republican because the Democrat party wont exist. So even though it looks like democracy, its not a true democracy, because even though on face value people get to choose between candidates, the candidates can't exert their free will and in the end the same party will continue to rule China till the end of time and hence the communism stays.

TL; DR: Its amazingly different from the US because you actually get a choice to vote for someone who doesn't have to follow a specific party ideal. So if such a system were going to be applied by a party to the country, it would fall hard in the next elections and probably wouldn't get elected till the people forgot about the incident. In China, the party has nothing to fear. Even if the people don't like their ideals they have no choice but to elect someone of the same party because, no other parties are allowed. Admittedly in the US, you don't exactly get a HUGE range of choice, but still its better than being a farce democracy where you have no rights to say and type whatever the hell you want about the government or the president and get away scott free.
